name: Chantcelle
comment info:
What do you notice? 
I notice that the graph displays percentages of Chinese imports of household items to the United States, despite the new coming tariffs being placed on foreign items. I also notice that lower quality items such as nail sets, artificial plants, and can openers have a much higher percentage of imports from China, rather than higher quality products like wood bookcases, and cars, which are likely made in the United States.
What do you wonder?
 I wonder if the amount of percentages of different products is based on materials used to make them or if it has to do with the pricing of making those different household items. Additionally, I wonder if the percentage of  imports is due to certain areas of manufacturing or how easy it is to import such larger objects compared to smaller ones. This shows us that relations of the U.S. with other major countries is important, and that without good terms, the prices and quantity of everyday items can quickly change.
How does this relate to you and your community?
 This relates to me and my community because it makes me wonder if we will be affected by the tariffs placed on these Chinese imports or if prices will change on basic home items. This can change the amount of products we see in the stores and how much more expensive they will become. 
Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.
 “Chinese Imports Change Due to Tariffs?”

name: James Miller Roe
comment info: Looking at this dissection of what goods come from China more frequently, I notice that a large amount of generic necessary goods are created in China. I notice that large goods are not made in China as often as compact goods. This is likely because of shipping and storing logistics. I wonder if there is some misleading information in this graph. It states that complex goods like cars and televisions are mostly made in America, but that doesn’t mean that the materials these goods are made of are made in China. I know that China and Taiwan are circuit manufacturing hubs of the world, so even if these goods are constricted in America, that does not mean that the individual components are made in America. This relates to my community because we are largely reliant on Chinese made goods. However, there are alternatives and it is possible on the individual level to limit consumption of unnecessary goods. Vetting what is an actually important purchase created freedom from the culture of over-consumption in America. Trade with China is important in my community, but it is also necessary to at least be self aware of consumption of novelty goods.

comment info:
1. As I analyze the image I notice that a majority of everyday household items are imported from China. These Chinese imports mainly come from plastic or other non-biodegradable items. I find it interesting how the United States relies so heavily on imported goods it is a very well developed country itself. 
2. 3. This relates to me and my community on many levels. 4. America is not as self-sufficient as you may think: We NEED China.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info:
@Kina Will
The environmental impact of creating such a mass of plastic goods is an important consideration. I know from following small startup companies that it is incredibly difficult to afford and manufacture injection molded plastic unless you use China. As for why China has been exporting so hard: China and other Asian countries rapidly industrialized following WW2. Mao's "Great Leap Forward" was an industrial campaign that led to the "purge of intellectuals" and the second largest famine in history. An estimated 45 million dies, but sources say anywhere from 15 to 55 million could be accurate. However large the death toll, the transition from agriculture to industrialization by force was largely successful. The sure of Chinese trade we are seeing now is a clear result of this industrialization campaign meeting a large demand for cheap "junk" goods. Because of the large population base and concentrated nature of this population in China, widespread factory work is the most optimal economic vehicle for socialized wealth creation.

name: Tamara Sadik
comment info:
I notice that many “everyday” essential items are manufactured and imported from China. Necessities such as first aid kits (90%), microwaves (90%), and toasters (>99%), are heavily manufactured within the country. In contrast, things such as rugs (9%), TV’s (10%), and wood closets (4%) are less in demand for manufacturing. The results from the data show how American consumers rely heavily on Chinese imports for certain products, especially tangible household items

I wonder why some products such as microwaves and toasters are almost entirely imported from China, while products such as rugs and TV’s are likely imported from other countries, instead of China.

 I also wonder if over-reliance on a single country like China for critical products can expose the U.S. to supply chain disruptions, as was made evident by PPE shortages during the COVID-19 pandemic. 


Recent tariffs on Chinese goods have led to increased costs for businesses, which are often passed on to consumers. This can result in higher prices for various products, including clothing, shoes, furniture, and electronics. Businesses in communities with a high reliance on imports from China, such as New York's Chinatown, have been particularly affected by these tariffs, with some facing a threat of closure.

Catchy Headline: A House of Cards: How Chinese Imports Impact the Average American Home.

I too think a lot about our over-reliance on a single country for so many of the day-to-day goods we use in our homes.  Do you feel that the tariffs might be good in that they will push us to rely less on other countries?  Or, will we have to make some drastic changes to how we go about our everyday lives?

name: Tareq Abolaban
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
I notice that many everyday household items have a very high percentage of products made in China. For example, first-aid kits (90%), umbrellas (98%), baby strollers (97%), and alarm clocks (>99%) are almost entirely from China. On the other hand, some items like mattresses (2%), cars (2%), and wood closets (4%) have very low percentages from China. This shows that Americans rely heavily on China for certain types of products, especially smaller household goods and electronics.

2. What do you wonder?
I wonder why some products, like alarm clocks or baby strollers, are almost entirely imported from China, while others, like cars and mattresses, are mostly made in the U.S. or other countries. I also wonder how this reliance might change if tariffs increase further, and whether these products could realistically be made in the U.S. without becoming extremely expensive.

3. How does this relate to you and your community?
This relates to me and my community because many of the products we use daily—like computers, kitchen appliances, or toys—are made in China. If these items suddenly became more expensive due to tariffs, it could impact household budgets and change shopping habits. For local businesses that sell these products, higher prices might reduce sales.

4. Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea:
"From China to Our Homes: How Dependent Are Americans on Imported Products?"

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi @Tareq Abolaban--Thank you for taking the time to share your thoughts and reflections.  You bring up such a good point when you question whether we can realistically make certain products here in the U.S., without making the products too expensive for consumers.  If we cannot do that, do you think this is going to change what households of the future will look like?  Will our lifestyles radically change if we stop using certain products altogether?  Are there things we rely on that we could do without?  There is so much to think about!

@Brody comets,
I am sorry this graph does not connect with you. It is definitely not a traditional textbook graph like a bar chart. Perhaps a more modern term for a graph is a “data visualization.” The overall intent is to tell a story about data using a picture. This graph is no different. Can you see how this graph uses colors to represent information and percentages to represent information? It also uses locations and different images to represent information. Can you tell what the percentages mean? Can you tell what the different colors represent? You might also read some of the other comments to better understand the graph. Give it a chance and I think you might grow to like these more creative types of graphs. Keep noticing and wondering!
